reviewText:
Early Access Review

There will be two reviews in one on this because of a previous version of the game and the Unreal remake of it.

The previous version is very promising in terms of what the unreal version will produce. Despite the graphics, getting stuck randomly and the look of items and rooms the game was enjoyable. The story was good but due to getting stuck and jumpscares not always appearing or something stopping them the game was harder to complete.

However, I have just completely playing the unreal version just now. Everything that gamers of the original game wanted is getting completely. Although updates are slower than other games, the updates are vast and add whole new details to the game. I appreciate that it now takes a little longer for the scares to start happening which I found enjoyable and likeable, to establish the setting and tension. Even with more scares, the game is really good.
Things to work on are
- The game rapidly drops in frame rate to 60fps down to 12 fps when I go near the fire or there is a lot of light even with light settings turned down
- More scares (that’s coming)
- When answering the phone, the camera battery would often die down very quickly meaning I would have to go to bed. The issue with this is that the audio continues playing and the protagonist continues talking in his sleep
- The SD card capacity reaches full amount and then I don't know what to do with it
- The subtitles at the introduction of the games start were too small and didn't notice them until mid-way through the whole speech.

Other than that would 100% recommend while the game is cheaper and it is good to have an audience voice with a dev that cares.

It's a budget unity game. The models are questionable, the soundfx quality is inconsistant and the script is just bad (the voice acting itself though is ok).

Even with these flaws I have to say this is the best horror game I have ever played. Slowly walking down the stairs and suddenly realizing that the couch has been hovering a foot off the ground the whole time is the kind of shock you can't get in a movie or book.

However everyone's fears are different so if you enjoyed movies like The Conjuring, Paranormal Activity, and Poltergiest you might want to play this game. If Halloween, Friday the 13, or even SAW are in your list of favorite horror movies then this possibly isn't a game you want to play

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the times that I with there was some another option other than yes or no when it came to recommending this game.  I personally like the IDEA of the gameplay and the concept, but I wouldn't go so far as to say that I love the general gameplay as it stands right now either.  Hopefully that'll make more sense as you continue to read my review, but let's get down to it.

In terms of graphics, it actually looks pretty decent for an indie game.  I've seen some people saying that their computers couldn't handle it...but I've got a Nvidia Geforce 610 GT and I managed to run the game with just about everything on whilst also getting some pretty decent frames, so seeing as how this is a 'work in progress' I'm sure that subject to change...for the good or otherwise.
When it comes to the camera effects and the SFX and whatnot, I'd say that's mostly where the game shines at in terms of graphics.  The distortions are done pretty well, there's some haze if you try to look at something in the distance, and the colors even begin to seperate when it rains (I.E. the water causes the camera to see Red, Green, and Blue).  Now, all this being said, there are some flaws here and there.  Some examples would be some textures looking...a bit outdated/out of place, randomly changing pictures (And not in the good way either...as in the paintings seem to be actually changing into something completely different before my eyes at times.  If that's part of the game, then just shoot me a message, but I'm pretty sure I saw one of those Michael Jackson paintings literally morph into one of the bathroom paintings.)

There are some things that I did kinda gripe about in the game that others might say was just me nitpicking, but personally they kinda stood out a lot.  For one thing the perspective of your character is...odd.  I feel like he's taller than the viewpoint may imply, as referenced by the furniture and whatnot, but whenever I attempted to interact with something I couldn't help but feel like I was incredibly short.  The rooms could have been a bit more interesting in my opinion, and the design of the house just felt...off.

Now the sound is one of the high points.  Listening to the game via my computer speakers doesn't do it enough justice, so I normally use my headphones when I play this game.  It does a fair job of immersing you into the game via sound, and it does help to make the game more atmospheric/scary.

When it comes to gameplay, the premise of the game is pretty basic.  You go around the house and record the strange occurances that happen there, or don't happen as the case may be.  You've got your flashlight, and you've also actually got a time limit on how long you can stay up before you have to charge your camera.  If you don't make it back to your bedroom before the battery hits zero then you die.  You can go around the house and collect/read the letters left behind by the previous owner, as well as learn the history of the house via the laptop, or you can learn about our main character's background.

The story is nothing special at all.  It's actually your typical 'Haunted House' type plot.  I understand that the game is supposed to be, more or less, of an homage to Paranormal Activity, but the story could really have been a bit less cliched in my opinion.  Not that you're required to even figure out the story, as you could just play the game without ever picking up a single note.

The scares aren't very scary.  I jumped due to...well, jump-scares, but that's it.  I never felt real-deal fear while I played the game, and some of the scares just felt a bit forced and really typical for me.  I get that they're dynamic to help make the game stay fresh, but that only works if the game continues to scare you...that never really happened for me.

This isn't going to affect my decision on how I'd rate this game, but if you came here with the expectation that the game would have fairly frequent updates...well, then you may want to look elsewhere.  As you could probably tell from the patch-notes about, the game hasn't been updated since April.  I don't currently know what the creator is doing as of right now, but I had heard that he has tried to fund the project through a website other than Kickstarter.  I currently don't know the name.

Personally, I don't know if I'd recommend this game as it stands.  I liked the idea/concept of this game, and I'd very much like to see how much farther it'll go during development, but as it stands it's just an alright game to me.  It offers nothing new in the way of gameplay, story, or otherwise, but at the same time the premise of the game is pretty appealing to those who like to try out new things.

***EDIT*** 7/1/15

So I've checked this game every chance that I've gotten since the latest update on New Year's Eve, and...nothing.  No updates, no latest news, nothing.  As I've stated before, it's not a bad game and it shows promise...but what's the point of promise if it just doesn't deliver?

Seriously, I've just about given up on the game at this point.  I could seriously care less about the game being converted to UE4.  Why not finish the UE3 version of the game first and work on the UE4 version second?  It'd certainly give us all something to do.

This early access explorational horror game has a lot of potential, with its promise of dynamic random gameplay; upcoming direct-X 11 graphics; and even future Oculus Rift support.  However at this current stage of development I find the game to be rather basic and generic, with its limited gameplay, controls, writing, and even audio and visuals.

Unfortunately the biggest let down for me was the horror part of Paranormal. Perhaps it is just a case of me having been desensitised by years of playing survival horror games, but I find the scares on offer here to be rather dull – they are all just too clichéd and expected, with your usual “ghost appearing in the mirror for a second” and “water turning bloody” type fares.  Overall the game has left me unfrightened, and to be honest unimpressed.

There will be two reviews in one on this because of a previous version of the game and the Unreal remake of it.

The previous version is very promising in terms of what the unreal version will produce. Despite the graphics, getting stuck randomly and the look of items and rooms the game was enjoyable. The story was good but due to getting stuck and jumpscares not always appearing or something stopping them the game was harder to complete.

However, I have just completely playing the unreal version just now. Everything that gamers of the original game wanted is getting completely. Although updates are slower than other games, the updates are vast and add whole new details to the game. I appreciate that it now takes a little longer for the scares to start happening which I found enjoyable and likeable, to establish the setting and tension. Even with more scares, the game is really good.
Things to work on are
- The game rapidly drops in frame rate to 60fps down to 12 fps when I go near the fire or there is a lot of light even with light settings turned down
- More scares (that’s coming)
- When answering the phone, the camera battery would often die down very quickly meaning I would have to go to bed. The issue with this is that the audio continues playing and the protagonist continues talking in his sleep
- The SD card capacity reaches full amount and then I don't know what to do with it
- The subtitles at the introduction of the games start were too small and didn't notice them until mid-way through the whole speech.

Other than that would 100% recommend while the game is cheaper and it is good to have an audience voice with a dev that cares.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After the death of his dog, young Mattel Clark has decided to investigate his house to capture the paranormal events that have been occurring. The artist may have gotten more than he bargained for...

With that creepy tagline out of the way, let's talk turkey here. Paranormal is a game inspired by the likes of The Blair Witch Project, Paranormal Activity, and Cloverfield. What it does is provide you with a startling haunted house-type simulator that offers jump scares and slowly simmering fear with a basic, perhaps shallow storyline that can vary in your playlength.

My tips for best game play? Always play unabridged. You'll get more scares that way. I still haven't experienced every scare yet and as of now, I'm starting to become too paranoid to experience them all. Collecting all of the collectibles is also a near impossible feat and you will get a visit from the succubus if you are attempting it.

Pros:

- Offers varied scares
- Game length can be short or long depending on your choices in game
- Replayability
- Bare bones storyline leaving you to investigate for clues
- Developer is rebuilding the game and is active in sharing what's next for Paranormal

Cons:
- Not your prettiest game
- Storyline could use a little more structure
- House layout can be confusing
- There is no save

I don't scare easily and I'm not a fan of the camera footage horror" film genres
date: but I did find the game enjoyable. If you're looking for combat or zombies
recommended: that's not here. You're at the mercy of the hauntings here and you're just recording it. There aren't any puzzles. You just walk around and watch the haunted house come to life. If you just want to be a little scared

Paranormal is terribly ugly.
as you can probably see, I didn't play much of it, probably not enough to get to the main parts of the game. But I've already encountered some annoying problems.
First, as I stated, the visuals. Paranormal shows that a good engine doesn't mean good graphics ; the house is a huge mess. The furniture feels like it's been placed randomly, every single room is huge but is empty. This emptiness allows the player to easily guess whats is going to happen ; the easiest example are the dummies.
They are randomly placed all over the main room, and  are going to gather around you at one time or another.
Still about the dummies, they were supposed to fall when I went down the stairs. They didn't. I bumped into an invisible wall, had to wait for a while before the dummies fell and I could move again.

Another visual problem is the head bobbing. I like head bobbing is first person games, but in Paranormal, the head bobbing feels like it's also controlled by the animations. Sometimes, the head will look at a particular point. I thought at first I was supposed to look at it, but no, it's just that sometimes, the hero feels like bowing his head, and suddenly getting it back up.

The idea behind Paranormal is good. It makes me think of The House in Underhell, but with more potential. We need to know more about the house before it gets creepy, we need to really control what we are doing, and most important, we shouldn't know what is going to try to scare us.

A lot of work is needed for this game to be good. Maybe later, it'll be interesting, but currently, it's a mess, in visuals, and gameplay.

There are glitches here and there as to be expected, so if getting to play a game in it's early stages is not your thing...you might wait for the finished version. If that kind of thing excites you, and you're a fan of horror games, do yourself a favor and pick this game up. I did happen to get my copy at a discount, but I think it's worth the ten dollars, and will certainly be worth it once the game is finished.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nParanormal, this game is amazing. It always keeps you on your feet. You happen to be a man named Marcus, trying to film strange happenings inside his house to have documented proof of the paranormal, however, he doesn't realize what is really in store for him. Early Access Review

Within the first half an hour this game had made me curse loudly multiple times. A genuinly unnerving and terrifying game at times. Unlike any other horror game I have played thus far, offering something different to likes of Amnesia, F.E.A.R (not the third I hasten to add, the first one which was scary) and slender, the three games that really defined the horror genre for me.
Obviously the game is inspired by films such as Paranormal Activity, but do not let that concept put you off. The concept of handheld camera footage and paranormal events occuring around the building translates exceptionally well to a game.
Being an early access game, I am truly excited for what will come next for Paranormal.
If you want you heart to race and to be unnerved whilst having a few excellent impromptu jumo scares along the way, look no further. At £6.99, this game is an absolute steal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I tried to capture the paranormal on my camcorder and all I got was 30 minutes of buyers remorse.

The game has always claimed to never play the same way twice, and yet I have yet to see a single playthrough that wasn't a complete silhouette of my first. There is no suspense or subtlety, only jump-scares. From the very first minutes of the very first day you can find levitating or moving objects, tryhard creepy posing-doll figures, and a whole bunch of hollow trope appearances. It really feels like the game is constantly rolling an RNG and randomly fires off a 'spooky' happening from a small list, and by the time your preset death occurs you will have likely seen the whole list. Some of the startle-scares try so hard that it actually becomes laughable, one of which is literally just a posing-doll ornament that just slides in under your view like a motion-tween HUD element, and then slides away again, without explanation or reaction from the character. Yeah. It's that kind of game.

I would have ADORED a game of genuine paranormal exposure and investigation in an enclosed space, but this is not that game it claims to be. I'm pretty sure the only kind of person that would enjoy this game is the kind of person that thinks a 'screamer' is 'horror'. Worse yet that a kickstarter was put up for a second area (yes, a second zone, in the first game) before the first area was even finished, and OH LOOK, it's STILL in early access!

Save your money. Watch a youtube lets play, and then you will have seen it all.
Don't believe me? Watch a few lets plays and see exactly how many differences you can find. You'll be able to count them on one hand.

Paranormal is terribly ugly.
as you can probably see, I didn't play much of it, probably not enough to get to the main parts of the game. But I've already encountered some annoying problems.
First, as I stated, the visuals. Paranormal shows that a good engine doesn't mean good graphics ; the house is a huge mess. The furniture feels like it's been placed randomly, every single room is huge but is empty. This emptiness allows the player to easily guess whats is going to happen ; the easiest example are the dummies.
They are randomly placed all over the main room, and  are going to gather around you at one time or another.
Still about the dummies, they were supposed to fall when I went down the stairs. They didn't. I bumped into an invisible wall, had to wait for a while before the dummies fell and I could move again.

Another visual problem is the head bobbing. I like head bobbing is first person games, but in Paranormal, the head bobbing feels like it's also controlled by the animations. Sometimes, the head will look at a particular point. I thought at first I was supposed to look at it, but no, it's just that sometimes, the hero feels like bowing his head, and suddenly getting it back up.

The idea behind Paranormal is good. It makes me think of The House in Underhell, but with more potential. We need to know more about the house before it gets creepy, we need to really control what we are doing, and most important, we shouldn't know what is going to try to scare us.

A lot of work is needed for this game to be good. Maybe later, it'll be interesting, but currently, it's a mess, in visuals, and gameplay.

Early Access Review

In 'Paranormal' you play as an artist who has rented their own personal studio where they can work on their art without being disturbed. But then you start to notice you may not be alone in the studio, no one believes you, so you decide to try and collect 'evidence'.

You don't actually collect evidence, but the developer uses it as an excuse to make your point of view through a fuzzy, crappy, pixelated video recorder that no one should have any business owning in 2015.

The entire game involves you wandering around your studio, trying to find proof the house is haunted. As you spend more time in the studio, you'll find little tidbits of information that help you slowly understand the haunting and the story behind it.

I tried to capture the paranormal on my camcorder and all I got was 30 minutes of buyers remorse.

The game has always claimed to never play the same way twice, and yet I have yet to see a single playthrough that wasn't a complete silhouette of my first. There is no suspense or subtlety, only jump-scares. From the very first minutes of the very first day you can find levitating or moving objects, tryhard creepy posing-doll figures, and a whole bunch of hollow trope appearances. It really feels like the game is constantly rolling an RNG and randomly fires off a 'spooky' happening from a small list, and by the time your preset death occurs you will have likely seen the whole list. Some of the startle-scares try so hard that it actually becomes laughable, one of which is literally just a posing-doll ornament that just slides in under your view like a motion-tween HUD element, and then slides away again, without explanation or reaction from the character. Yeah. It's that kind of game.

I would have ADORED a game of genuine paranormal exposure and investigation in an enclosed space, but this is not that game it claims to be. I'm pretty sure the only kind of person that would enjoy this game is the kind of person that thinks a 'screamer' is 'horror'. Worse yet that a kickstarter was put up for a second area (yes, a second zone, in the first game) before the first area was even finished, and OH LOOK, it's STILL in early access!

Save your money. Watch a youtube lets play, and then you will have seen it all.
Don't believe me? Watch a few lets plays and see exactly how many differences you can find. You'll be able to count them on one hand.

As of writing, the Unreal Engine 3 version of the game remains unfinished but work is still being done on it's Unreal Engine 4 version, sticking to the same jumpscare-horror. Both versions remain unfinished.

What is Paranormal?
Genre: Indie, Horror, Early Access
Developer: Matt C. Cohen (single entity)
Producer: Matt C. Cohen (single entity)
Release Date: 19 Oct, 2012
Review Author: ScottyNOW

'Paranormal', not to be confused with the 'Paranormal Activity' movie series. Paranormal, the video game, implements the same concept of poltergeists that cause havoc across houses, a nightmare for 'nannies' and cleaners alike. The story revolves around an artist (protagonist) in his place of residence, he is determined to understand what is going on around him as things seem to go 'bump' in the night; attempting to gain closure and regain his sanity from the footage gathered.

Audience and Verdict

I believe youtubers and horror fanatics (i.e me and you) will receive the most enjoyability out of this, I also recommend for the best consumer experience is to switch off any external lights and use with headphones. The experience wasn't revolutionary and other games seem to do the same thing better, regardless of this, the game itself is a work-in-progress, and as such, a pricetag of $5/£3.47/€4.41 is comendable at best. I honestly don't believe in the 3+ years of development that any groundbreaking progress has happened and this game is more of a hobby that the game developer tinkers with in his spare time than an actual game that will gain constant updates and with that in mind, I do NOT recommend it.
